> ken,
> I quit being suprised anymore. Everytime I think I've got a great idea,
> you post a link to the paper you wrote on it.
> So the conclusion was that it was good for input types that are easily
> scalable, like vision processing. That is certainly important to me. Do
> you have that framework for folks like me to play with?

Hi Chad,

Since I'm the author of that software I figured I should reply. The short
answer is yes, the code exists. :) The long answer is that yes it exists,
but its not very well commented nor particularly user friendy (though it
does have a similar structure to Ken's implementation). Basically I wrote
a version of NEAT from scratch with the "genes as networks" idea firmly in
mind, so the code organization really reflects that fundamentally. My
original design really needs to be refactored since there are several very
cruel bits of code that are necessary for it to function.

That being said, I'd be more than happy to send you a copy of everything
and help out with getting it to run on your system (its all linux code,
but should port more or less directly since the newtork rendering is
separate). Basically there is no public release because 1) I haven't had a
lot of time to clean up the code and 2) fundamentally the idea we tried is
a little shaky and could be done better (particularly, if you read the
paper, separating the subnetworks and expression information genetically
does not seem to be the best idea).

Joe

-- 

Joseph Reisinger
http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/joeraii
